moves.1. e4 d5: This game was in a Scandinavian Defense mini-tournament.
moves.3. d3: ?! Not a book move and very passive, blocking the light squared bishop. More common is 3.Nc3.
moves.4. a3: ? Wastes a tempo. ...Bb4+ is not a threat here.
moves.6... Nf6 7. Bg5 Be7 8. Bxf6: ? Gives up the bishop pair for nothing.
moves.8... Bxf6 9. Qe2: ? Blocks in the f1-bishop even further, and allows my next move.
moves.9... Nd4: Violates the principle, 'Move every piece once before you move any piece twice unless there is a tactic,' but this move does not lose a tempo because white's queen is forced to move again and keep an eye on the c2 square. My knight position improves, but white's queen position does not, so this is a free beneficial move.
moves.10. Qd2 Bd7: Preparing queenside castling. I want my rook on the d-file.
moves.11. Nge2: GK computer says this is an inaccuracy because of 11...Bg5 12.Qd1 f5, but what if 12.Qxg5? Then 12...Nxc2+ wins a rook, but there likely would be tactical complications with open lines on the kingside and the a1 knight trying not to get trapped. I considered 11...Bg5 but preferred a lead in development, pressure, active pieces, and the bishop pair to being up the Exchange with complications.
moves.11... O-O-O: Should I have played 11...Bg5? Is it better?
moves.12. O-O-O Rhe8 13. Kb1: ?! Wastes a tempo in my opinion. I would have tried to get the f1 bishop out via g3, Rg1, and Bg2.
moves.13... Bc6: This move turns the f1 bishop into a tall pawn on the 1st rank, and clears the path of the d8-rook.
moves.14. Nxd4: Logical move, trades a 2nd rank knight for a 5th rank knight.
moves.14... Rxd4: I recaptured this way to make my rook more powerful.
moves.15. f3: The f1 bishop is completely useless now.
moves.15... Red8: Doubling rooks to increase the pressure on the d-file.
moves.16. Be2 h6: Threatening 17...Bg5 then ...f5 and ripping open the center.
moves.17. Qe1 Bg5: Unblocking the f-pawn to prepare ...f5 and an attack in the center.
moves.19. h4 Be7: I changed plans and now target white's king.
moves.20. g3: Trying to restrain the kingside/central attack.
moves.20... b5: Pawn storm. My pieces' activity and open lines compared to white's passivity and blocked pieces means that my king is safe while white's king is not.
moves.22. Na2: ? Computer says best was 22.axb4 Bxb4 and only a small disadvantage for white.
moves.23. b3 a5: The a-pawn prepares to advance and attack the weak b3-pawn.
moves.25. b4: ? Best was 25.Nc1. This costs white about 1 pawn worth according to the computer.
moves.26. Ka1: ?? Loses to the computer recommended next move.
moves.26... Bxe1: ?? Logical move: attack the king, win material, simplify, then win the endgame. But better was 26...Qc4!! and 27.dxc4 loses so computer gives best play as 26…Qc4 27.Kb1 Bc3 28.dxc4 Rxd1+ 29.Nc1 Rxe1 30.Qxe1 Bxe1.
moves.27. Qxe1: Loses the f3 pawn but it makes no difference already.
moves.30. Qe1: ?? 30.c3 was much better according to computer.
moves.30... Rd4xd3+ 31. c3 Rd3d1 32. Qf2: If 32.Rxd1 then 32...Rxd1+ wins a queen for a rook.
moves.32... Rxb1+ 33. Kxb1 Qb6+: ?? 33...Rd1+ and mate in 12! But simplification is good enough to win.
